children.subject:
"Math 54 is useful but only in EE 16A did I appreciate linear algebra."

I think Math 54 is useful, but its not applications focused. EE 16A teaches you a lot of the same material, but teaches you applications of each linear algebra topic as well.

Math 54 is theoretical but also very practical since the concepts taught are used in a lot of different places in CS. I'm not sure why you think its not useful. Do you mean an applications based class? Try CS189 maybe.

Try EE128 Feedback Control.  You get to find out how vector spaces, basis, rank, and null space all relate

to getting the best possible performance out of physical systems.  Labs include real-world examples

like stabilizing an inverted pendulum and magnetic levitation, but applications include anything

with behavior governed by differential equations (which is basically everything from machines to networks

to economics), and all of it is very closely tied to some beautiful mathematics.

Understand the math, control the world!
OP Here. Looks interesting! Added it to my classes to take list!

EPS 104: Mathematical Methods for Geophysics. It does cover a lot of earth science (fluid mechanics, continuum mechanics, etc.), but it is mostly math. It essentially covers most of Math 121A/B: review of vectors, matrices, and tensors, Fourier series, how to solve various types of differential equations, Green's function, Bessel's function, Fourier transforms, complex analysis/integration, and convolution. The professor is awesome and really enthusiastic about the material.
OP Here. Same question. Seems interesting but I have no idea what to expect.
Anyone have thoughts on INDENG 166 (Decision Analysis)? I might take it in the future.

history.content:
I really love "practical" math courses. In other words, math courses that teach you to solve real world problems. 

For example, CS 70 and EE 126 give you the tools (Markov Chains, Expectation, etc) to model a lot of real world phenomena. On the other hand, Math 54 is really theoretical: Vector spaces, basis, rank, null space. Math 54 is useful but only in EE 16A did I appreciate linear algebra.

So, my question is, what other practical math courses do you suggest? They don't need to be in Math DepartmentThey don't even need to be math courses: Game Theory isn't math but (1) its practical and (2) it's analysed like math. 

Here are some I'd like, please suggest more!

- STAT 150: Stochastic Processes
- STAT 153: Intro to Time Series
- STAT 155: Game Theory

- INDENG 166: Decision Analysis

- INDENG 267: Queueing Theory

- PUB POL 259: Cost Benefit Analysis

- PHIL 143: Modal Logic
history.subject: Practical Math/Stats Courses

history.content:
I really love "practical" math courses. In other words, math courses that teach you to solve real world problems. 

For example, CS 70 and EE 126 give you the tools (Markov Chains, Expectation, etc) to model a lot of real world phenomena. On the other hand, Math 54 is really theoretical: Vector spaces, basis, rank, null space. Math 54 is useful but I didn't enjoy it nearly as much as 70 or 126. Only in EE 16A did I appreciate linear algebra.

So, my question is, what other practical math courses do you suggest? They don't need to be in Math DepartmentThey don't even need to be math courses: Game Theory isn't math but (1) its practical and (2) it's analysed like math. 

Here are some I'd like, please suggest more!

- STAT 150: Stochastic Processes
- STAT 153: Intro to Time Series
- STAT 155: Game Theory

- INDENG 166: Decision Analysis

- INDENG 267: Queueing Theory

- PUB POL 259: Cost Benefit Analysis

- PHIL 143: Modal Logic
